awd_titl_txt: Soil Suction Surrogates for Advancing Complete-Stress-State Solutions to Expansive Soils
awd_abstract_narration:
Approximately 320 million hectares of the world's land is covered with expansive clays that are subject to shrinkage and swelling in response to changes in soil moisture conditions.  Damage to U.S. public infrastructure from expansive clays is estimated to be $15 B/yr.  For every billion dollars in damage from unconservative design, perhaps $10B is lost from overly conservative design.  Expansive clays are unsaturated soils in that the void space between clay particles is filled partly with air and partly with water. However, common approaches to dealing with expansive soils do not fully consider the unsaturated soil aspects that drive infrastructure damage.  This award supports the development of an innovative approach to bringing unsaturated soil mechanics theory into wide use in dealing with infrastructure development on expansive clay profiles.  Due to the magnitude of expansive soils problems, and the involvement of 10s of thousands of practitioners addressing these problems, this study will provide societal benefit through saving billions of dollars annually on U.S. infrastructure.  The project has numerous outreach components, including cross-training between researchers and practicing engineers that will improve engineering education.  Participation of underrepresented students and returning-veteran students will broaden the impact of this study through development of more diverse and well-trained work force. 

A dual approach will be taken for estimation of expansive soil swell-shrinkage movements, wherein a fundamentals-based soil suction and net normal stress approach will be linked to a surrogate-based approach.  The method will embrace principles of unsaturated soils theory, yet expand applicability through well-founded yet commonly-measured soil suction surrogate parameters.  Climatic effects (including site-specific 'microclimate') will be incorporated into surrogate parameter determination, consistent with recent research on soil surface-atmosphere interactions. This research fills a gap between theory and the vast amount of available field data.  A fundamentally-based soil suction surrogate will facilitate use of the huge database of soil parameters available from past expansive soil investigations. Simple functions of water content and index properties will be used - in lieu of soil suction - to evaluate expansive soil movements for partial wetting or drying under field net normal stress conditions.  The primary goal is to develop a soil suction surrogate approach that yields exactly the same, or essentially the same, expansive soil movement  results as the complete-stress-state based suction approach, and which allows geotechnical engineers to take advantage of their vast experience from a more fundamental perspective.

por.por_cntn:
Damage to U.S. public infrastructure from expansive clays alone is estimated to be $15 billion/yr., yet current geotechnical engineering strategies for expansive soils incorporate high degrees of uncertainties of field stress state for use in analyses. The findings of this study facilitate the use of established principles of unsaturated soil mechanics theory in the design and analyses of infrastructure placed in and on expansive soils. A unique method was developed by which data available in existing geotechnical engineering reports and historical literature can be used to expand the database of profiles of field stress state, including in particular field soil suction values. The expanded database was then used to develop soil suction profiles for common field situations, and across a wide range of climatic conditions.  Climatic effects, consistent with recent research results on soil surface-atmosphere interactions, were included in the estimation of soil suction profiles, as were fundamental unsaturated moisture flow principles.  A new method for computation of expansive soil movements was developed for use with the enhanced estimates of field-appropriate soil stress state conditions.

 

A primary research goal was to provide a surrogate (substitute) for soil suction that allows engineers to take advantage of their vast experience and existing database of field moisture state conditions from a more fundamental perspective. Through enhanced confidence brought about with improved understanding field stress state conditions, smarter landscape irrigation practices, mitigation solutions, and minimally   resource-intensive foundation systems for expansive soils can be achieved.

The project also had numerous outreach and educational components. The project included outreach to veteran civil engineering students through coordination with Arizona State University?s Office for Veteran and Military Academic Engagement (designed to help veterans and students from diverse backgrounds achieve their educational and career goals). Two veteran students joined the study as undergraduates, and both of these students successfully completed masters? degrees. In total, 3 MSE students and 1 PhD student completed theses/dissertations based on this study.   All findings from this study have been disseminated through local and national meetings, and through publication in journals and conference proceedings. As a part of this study GIS-based maps/software was developed for determining the Thornthwaite Moisture Index climate parameter (TMI), based on latitude and longitude. This contribution is available to the public.

The development of the suction surrogate is likely to encourage more routine use of soil suction based methods for estimation of expansive soil movements.  Soil suction based methods are the best methods for estimation of soil heave but use has been hindered by challenges in obtaining soil suction values due to limited available field data.  This project has resulted in a substantial enhancement of the database of field-appropriate soil suction profiles for use in analyses of expansive soils.
